target_title: Add support for relocatable application bundle
Ship translations / language files in our Windows binary

note.body:
As the comment in `meld.conf` there says, `_` and `ngettext` are installed from the main `meld` script, where we do (among a bunch of other things):

```python
trans = gettext.translation(
    locale_domain, localedir=str(locale_dir), fallback=True)
_ = meld.conf._ = trans.gettext
meld.conf.ngettext = trans.ngettext
```

As for the rest of the translation infrastructure, it's been a very long time since I looked at how this all ties together, or whether there's a more modern way to initialise the necessary parts. I know that this doesn't work in Windows, though the actual reason escapes me. Best I know this should more-or-less work on macOS, though I definitely haven't looked at it.

target_title: `meld` segfault + freeze

note.body: Damn, must have accidentally check-marked the “confidential” thingy... please remove.. it is **not** confidential.

target_title: `meld` segfault + freeze
Ship translations / language files in our Windows binary

note.body:
Even if the Windows-specific issues are fixed, I believe translations won't work because the code is full off
```python
from meld.conf import _
```
and in `meld.conf` is
```python
# Installed from main script
def no_translation(gettext_string: str) -> str:
    return gettext_string

_ = no_translation
ngettext = no_translation
```

I don't understand how translations could work on any platform with this.

edit: I see now that most of the UI related strings come from `.ui` files. The mechanism responsible for translating them is a different can of worms.

target_title: With 2 screens, `meld` opens under the menu bar

note.body:
Although I cannot reproduce that exact issue on my end, it fits right into the occasional quirkiness in window behavior of GTK 3 apps on macOS. Can you use the exposé function to move the window? Are you also having trouble moving the app from one monitor to the other and back again (because that doesn't really work for me)?

At least some part of the issue is caused by the usage of [CSD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Client-side_decoration) instead of native window decorations. I've begun porting the macOS integration work that Youssef has done in his fork to mitigate this. You can try a development snapshot from [this pipeline](https://gitlab.com/dehesselle/meld_macos/-/pipelines/1603690365/builds) and see if that helps.

Sorry again for being so careless when writing this report. Yes, it’s obviously `git difftool` command.

I’m following the `echo '/Applications/Meld.app/Contents/MacOS/Meld "$@"' > /usr/local/bin/meld` instruction, but I think it lacks the `chmod a+x /usr/local/bin/meld` command.

Yes, now, it works.

Maybe it’s because `git` was, sometimes, doing this error to me:
```
git difftool -d 
git(44818,0x7ff850624f80) malloc: *** error for object 0x7ff80d00cb8f: pointer being freed was not allocated
git(44818,0x7ff850624f80) malloc: *** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug
Abort trap: 6
```
I’m speculating here.

Thanks, Antoine

@dehesselle : my bad. It’s -d, for directory compare.

- Machine: Mac- mini8,1
- Kernel:  23.6.0
- OS:      macOS 14.7.1 Sonoma
- meld:    3.23.0

~/.gitconfig:
```
[diff]
	tool = meld
[difftool "meld"]
	cmd = meld "$LOCAL" "$REMOTE"
[difftool "bbdiff"]
	prompt = false
	cmd = bbdiff -w --resume "$LOCAL" "$REMOTE"
	
[merge]
	tool = meld
[mergetool]
	tool = meld
	prompt = false
	keepBackup = false
[mergetool "meld"]
    cmd = meld "$LOCAL" "$BASE" "$REMOTE" --output "$MERGED"
[mergetool "bbdiff"]
	prompt = false
	cmd = bbdiff -w --resume "$LOCAL" "$REMOTE"
```

Cordialement, Antoine

[Feature Request] Add option `Accept Combination` for 3 way merge conflict solving

note.body:
Hi there, thank you for your time and the reply. Actually, this 3 way merge tool has basically 3 options to kind of cover a merge conflict:

- Take over the current HEAD diff resp. commit.
- Take over the incoming from the new commit while merge/rebase.
- Or create take over a combination of both of the changes (this happens when we rebase for example)

What I especially like is the accept combination feature, which is basically the 3rd option.

![image](/uploads/6ca340668c85d9a9ab5837748c6fb7e4/image.png)

I think this image kind of represents the idea. If both commits have changes that are kind of overlapping, but not an incremental, one might opt for one followed the other changes.

[VSCode 3-way Merge Editor](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/sourcecontrol/overview#_3way-merge-editor)

I hope, I could clarify your issue. :smile:

target_title: Incorrect diff visual element when a file and a dir have same name

note.body:
I agree that this display is not good, but the more I think about it the more I don't know what it should actually look like. One option would be to - as I think you're suggesting - have

\> ~~ciao~~      \> ciao \
\> folder     \> folder \
ciao            ~~ciao~~

This *would* be a more accurate representation of the state, but I am worried it would also make it much easier to miss the fact that these are essentially conflicting file names.

Possibly we could introduce a different warning state here as well to indicate the conflict, though it might be tricky.

Also worth noting is that given other existing behaviours, we can't *not* show the folder expand next to the file version of `ciao` that's matched to the folder version, because the folder version needs to have the expander (so that we can show the files under it) and the widget doesn't allow us to customise whether a row with children does or doesn't show the expander. The row has children and so it *must* have the expander, best I know.

target_title: [Feature Request] Add option `Accept Combination` for 3 way merge conflict solving

note.body:
I feel like there are a couple of different requests here. Doing inline highlighting on the difference between the local and remote versions is tricky in our three-pane setup, but also is a very old request (see #44). I would love to get around to this, but haven't.

Making an option for the three pane layout you show is very unlikely to happen unless someone wants to start making major contributions to enable it. I understand the benefits there, but also it's a major piece of work.

The actual title of your request however is for an "Accept combination" button and I still don't understand what that button *does*. In your screenshot above, what would actually happen if I clicked that button?

The fix will be in the next stable release. Thanks for your bug report.

target_title: Meld macOS port

note.body:
Many thanks to @dehesselle for bringing in a build pipeline to get macOS packages avaiable, however @dafkam is right to re-open as that was only one part (albeit the biggest) of the actual issue raised.

You are right about not attempting a take-over of the existing brew package, but it might make sense to create an alternative brew package such as `meld-gnome` which is clearly not the same software as `meld`, so will not over-set expectations. This is an approach that [the homebrew project considers acceptable](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Casks#not-a-fork-usually).

Although I have never created a brew package myself I believe we would [make a 'cask'](https://docs.brew.sh/Cask-Cookbook) (the package definition file for a GUI app) and we would designate the `homepage` to the main meld project page, that way people would raise any issues here instead of on one of the developers or maintainers forks.

If we do not yet have a build available on the main project page, we _could_ consider tagging the build delivered by brew as `@beta` but that is a subject beyond my knowledge (even as a user).

target_title: Meld macOS port

note.body: Yet another input that I was concerned by the Homebrew warning that meld was deprecated, and apparently will be disabled in Homebrew entirely on December 17th (10 days from now). It would be good to at least have some intermediate build available via homebrew in the meantime if possible, though I agree that an official upstream release for brew to pull from is the best long-term solution.

target_title: Meld macOS port

note.body:
@ilyagr 
> This wasn't possible recently as I complained [in another issue](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/meld/-/issues/837#note_2283271 "running on macOS from upstream meld source"). Now, **it is again possible**, [...]

Despite any settings for expiration, GitLab [always keeps the latest artifact for a given ref](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/jobs/job_artifacts.html#keep-artifacts-from-most-recent-successful-jobs) around. So you can't stick to a specific pipeline/job for long, you have to always look for the latest one.

---

@dafkam My first priority is to get an official macOS release on https://meld.app. I do neither control nor know when the next release is going to happen (I do not want to put any pressure on Kai). Once it does, I hope we'll be able to catch people's attention to help upstream Youssef's work here.

I do not use Homebrew myself and would leave that to someone else. If nobody updates the cask, I'll eventually do it myself. Technically I could already do it, because I can use my code to build Meld.app regardless of upstream's official release cycle. But I see problems:
- it would come from my repo and not from upstream
- people will come to me with their issues
- people won't like that a completely different fork takes over the cask which is noticeable due to initial loss of functionality (that is only present in Youssef's fork)

I am hesitant to open that can of worms.

target_title: Meld macOS port

note.body:
> You can grab development snapshots [directly from CI pipelines](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/meld/-/pipelines?page=1&scope=all&ref=main).

This wasn't possible recently as I complained [in another issue](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/meld/-/issues/837#note_2283271). Now, **it is again possible**, as there is a new development CI artifact (labeled as "Ukranian translation"). See the screenshot in the linked comment for a hint of how to do it.

As https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/meld/-/issues/837 discusses, the docs for running a Mac OS build on ARM on the wiki are out of date. I might try to fix them, but the intermittent availability of the artifact is not encouraging. I would also have to put a draft edit in an issue and hope somebody updates the Wiki. I stumbled upon the above problem when I first tried, though my linked complained itself might be helpful for leading people to download the correct artifact.

target_title: running on macOS from upstream meld source
More readable inline differences highlighting

note.body: Meld's defaults are chosen specifically to be fairly easy on the eyes, so I'm not likely to change our default theme like this, no. However, these are implemented via GtkSourceView style schemes, so you can make the change yourself locally. If you check out the `meld:inline` style in `meld-base.style-scheme.xml` in your Meld install, you can make additional changes there.

target_title: More readable inline differences highlighting
Do not highlight filtered differences

note.body:
I have looked at this, and unfortunately while I understand the point you're making here, I'm not willing to do this.

I started off being unsure because I think both what we currently show and what you're asking for are both slightly misleading in different ways, and I was trying to decide which of the two was likely to be less confusing. I decided that I agreed with you that highlighting filtered-out text is probably less obvious. 

However, having spent some time looking at the relevant code... there's just no practical way I'm going to make this change. The highlighting code is already convoluted, and adding a text-filter post-processing step to it would make it so much worse that I'm absolutely convinced that it's not worth it. I looked at whether it could be done using GtkSourceView styles, but it can't because we applying the ignore tags to everything in the document without current chunk type information. Even if we could have that passed through, I don't know that it's possible to clear out a tag to take it back to the previously set background.

Anyway, I appreciate that this isn't what you want here, but unfortunately I simply don't see this happening. Thanks anyway for your bug report.

target_title: Do not highlight filtered differences
Update Ukrainian translation

note.body: I'm sorry, but I don't usually handle MRs for translations. Translations are handled by the GNOME translation team. I'd suggest that you contact the translation team for your language (https://l10n.gnome.org/teams/uk/) about getting your changes merged.

target_title: Meld hangs on open, no diff highlighting + spinner (GDK_BACKEND=broadway)

note.body:
When the repaint is sufficiently slow, the spinner means that we never get to idle, which to the user comes across as a hang. This is a known thing and while ideally I'd rewrite the idle job handling, that's not likely to happen any time soon.

The only realistic thing that could happen here is that we'd hide the spinner entirely if we're running on a broadway backend. I don't know whether it's possible to detect that, but if so then that would be a feasible change.

target_title: feat: highlight permission difference

note.body:
I'm sorry but I don't think that most users would expect a permission difference to cause a file to be identified as "different". I appreciate that this is something that is useful sometimes, but I think it needs a much, much more limited indicator.

I'm not even sure that I'd expect files that differed only in permissions to show up with the "modified" filter enabled at all. Possibly this would be an argument for splitting the "modified" filter into what the comparison would consider modified, though that would be a large change.

target_title: bug in the french interface

note.body: I don't know what version of Meld this is, but this translation appears to have been fixed four and a half years ago, so I'm going to close this.

target_title: bug in the french interface
Cannot use relative directories in meldcmp files with change from paths to uris

note.body:
I don't intrinsically object to the idea of supporting this, though I wouldn't put it in the `uri` entry. I would definitely look at a patch that added support for loading from a `path` entry instead (giving preference to `uri` if it was there). This seems like it would be a fairly simple and non-invasive patch, and if so I would be fine merging that.

However, I do think this might hit some issues with us trying to re-save to the file. Because we're co-opting GNOME's recent files stuff in a slightly weird way, we maintain and clean the list ourselves somewhat manually, so it might need to be smarter about knowing whether to write out a path or a URI, and that's where I feel like this might fail. If we get to the point of having to pass additional metadata to file/folder comparisons to support roundtripping this information... I don't know if I'd merge that, simply because the use case is I think fairly rare, and I'm not willing to add that much complexity to support it.

target_title: error when matching regular expressions
error when matching regular expressions

note.body:
This highlighting is done by GtkSourceView, so moving the issue there.

I am not a regex expert, but I am not convinced that your desired behaviour is actually expected. I just checked Python's engine and it doesn't match the full foobar string unless it's first in the pattern. I would also expect the engine to stop at the first match rather than trying to find a longer one.

target_title: meld hangs when reloading a updated file

note.body: There should be no difference between a reload like that and an initial load, so I'm not sure what would cause this. If you have files you can upload that reproduce the problem, that would help a lot.

target_title: Display only lines that differ (hide unchanged lines)

note.body:
I find it valuable when a few minor changes in a very long file (with many **un**changed lines of code inbetween the changes) are displayed in a way that doesn't require endless scrolling. I'm actually a bit surprised not to see this in Meld, I think it's a very intuitive thing to do when diffing.

For example, JetBrains tools can do this - there is a button for collapsing (hiding) the unmodified sections. It's literally just a UI thing, nothing genuinely "functional" (regarding the diff-ing logic etc.) See screenshots below and pay attention to the curved line in the middle.

![jetbrains_diff_uncollapsed](/uploads/17938ba3f981a230bedd011aff3f0f31/jetbrains_diff_uncollapsed.png)
![jetbrains_diff_collapsed](/uploads/5bde6f8949acae2695af59f9b3c3c079/jetbrains_diff_collapsed.png)

I've done a little bit of work on a PyQt project, but that was years ago and GTK is a different beast anyway. Still, I'll try to poke around the code just to get some idea about the feasibility.

Off-topic: given the trolling by the OP, I'd prefer to create a new issue, but it would probably be a duplicate.

target_title: Keyboard shortcuts interfere with Swiss-German Layout (Windows)

note.body:
Sorry for the confusing description.
To write a backslash, I have to type `<altgr>-<` which is then interpreted as the `<alt>-\` shortcut.
Maybe this is just some strange windows gtk issue..

target_title: Keyboard shortcuts interfere with Swiss-German Layout (Windows)

note.body: I cannot follow. If \\ already has a dedicated key on your keyboard layout why would you combine with AltGr? What does that key do when using it without any modifier?

target_title: Keyboard shortcuts interfere with Swiss-German Layout (Windows)
Request: Switch focus between open panes, using keyboard

note.body: 4 years later I'm coming back to my own issue to find these shortcuts again. I'm using 3.20.4, and shortcuts are still shown for Fullscreen, Stop, Refresh, and many items under other menus, but not for Previous/Next Pane. But I'm on an old LTS so maybe the situation is improved by 3.22.2.

[Need more GTK2 version anyone?] Tried to edit Wiki but can't log in/edit after register, could reset passwd.

note.body: I started with an old version and have slowly been applying commits that can work, i agree though. Python2 is becoming a pain, having just dealt with the dependencies to make meld-1.8 usable again i can understand why python and all fell into un-maintained, the python2 version in debian as i discovered is actuslly python-minimal and was lacking, i think i read somewhere that the python2 usage had fallen down to 4% a few months ago too. It's fun doing stuff like this though. Especially when it works. And what im learning doing this i can apply going forward and maybe I can be of use here knowing at least a bit about how stuff ties together.

target_title: [Need more GTK2 version anyone?] Tried to edit Wiki but can't log in/edit after register, could reset passwd.

note.body:
It's a very niche use case im after. 'Myself and that one other guy' and I eant to try to use MUI2GTK and see if i can run it on an Amiga. The speed of gtk-2 on older systems is also important, this is likely due to the rendering path gtk3+ taked and the fact that all these older systems ( like my PoweBook G4 ) just struggles to cope much at all anymore.

And then there are the things in the newer versions of Meld (i.e after gtk3) i just dont like having lost, like the right click to jump get a file listing to jump to, id say i now maybe know meld well enough to try and borrow that from Geany , the editor, now, meld lost that festure quite some time ago, i cant say i can relate to the UI at all anymore nor have I really used GNOME after gtk3, it's for fun and learning i do this, not to create a hugely popular fork everyone will suddenly jump to.

target_title: [Need more GTK2 version anyone?] Tried to edit Wiki but can't log in/edit after register, could reset passwd.

note.body:
I manages to satisfy all deps, gtksourceview and pygrksourceview .debs and and all built on Debian SID, the deps are a bit hacky, and pycairo im just going to... Not, i think.. The (full and proper) python2 package with the python2.pm and dh_python2 i did to build pycairo is really not necessary. All i need to figure out is why meld doesn't obay .gtkrc anymore... 

https://github.com/threader/meld-1.8 - lives again \ ('') /

Edit. Well thats the theme sorted. Edit: Ok, mostly, I have found a new and creative way of segfaulting meld on startup, sometimes. It apparently also loads the button images trough osmosis, sometimes it spews the logs, sometimes not, but always loads the .png's... There are more pressing issues though, but this was fun.

target_title: [Need more GTK2 version anyone?] Tried to edit Wiki but can't log in/edit after register, could reset passwd.

note.body: I got the deps, pygtk-2.24 built, hacked around a few deficiencies, and removed the check-local flag from the makefile of pygyk, but meld-1.8 is running! No .deb though, for whatever reason, dh_buildpackage wants to use dh_systemd_enable and its supposed to use dh_installsystemd , a problem with the cdbs package.

[Need more GTK2 version anyone?] Tried to edit Wiki but can't log in/edit after register, could reset passwd.

note.body:
Thanks, I will keep this in mind, i feel the newer versions, from the first gtk-3 version meld really, never felt natural to use for me, gtk-3/gnome3 at all neither felt ' at home with me ' i guess its my retro roots. 

i will need to solve running 1.8 agian though, im currently/and have for quite some time been using the one in debian sid because i have not really had time/the need or lust, to solve getting the GTK-2 version running again on newer systems, i did grab some deps and make some notes occasionally though and commit that. Someone even forked it and did a thing i spotted some moons ago.  https://github.com/embeddedt/meld-gtk2 

Speaking og GTK-2, i found a dirt old theme i did in the bowels of my backups, i went nuts trying to get old drives recovered some years ago with dd-rescue and whatever i did, i got back to 2006 \0/ https://github.com/threader/Xfce4-dusk-2 i actually have no real idea how old that is, i do remember some gtk-3 breakeage last time i tried it but the GTK-2 theme i really liked. I based it off a theme i used to use that came with Audacious, the media player, when that started disappearing, i decided I'd try to preserve the theme for myself, just some tweaks to the images was basically what i ended with and never really finished or the gtk-3 side or be really happy with the outcome of ghe gtk-3 side compated to 2. I uploaded it to xfce4 look.org 'back in the day' but i couldn't find either that nor my account last i tried. The gtk-3 stuff i was trying to learn a bit, i remember my tab underline borders being a bit big and scroll bar a bit small, but that is apparently the norm now anyway. 

Anywho, I though I'd pay some gtk-x and python2 stuff a visit again along the way here, I'll be looking into the PPC stuff again and other stuff i can do on quiet laptops for a while. I need to revisist this (xnu_gcc_libc_etc_darwin), xnu and darwin-build (if that still exists), i feel the need to sort out booting everything to my liking and figure out what i can do with (xnu_gcc_libc_etc_darwin) with my understanding now. I think basically one of my xnu kernel there could drop into that 'osx 10.6.8 on unsupported PPC' or what to call that project https://forums.macrumors.com/threads/snow-leopard-on-unsupported-powerpc-macs.2232031/ - i came and checked and had xnu_gcc_libc_etc_darwin just in time to enjoy some building by a series of conicidences, basically apple left enough ppc binaries in beta and early releases to assemble a working ppc one, my ATI PowerBook didn't have gfx acceleration last i checked though so i will probably strip that to finder and a terminal or something and boot off USB or at first.
 https://github.com/threader/xnu_gcc_libc_etc_darwin - and vist the 'Darling project' https://github.com/darlinghq/darling ofc, I've been wanting to do that for years, i might as well make some recovey that and juggles YaBoot to boot MorphOS and Grub2-ppc a bit to get to know that (mess) too while i try to force install osx from commands i dug up to run in the installer/recovey env. of osx some 12 years ago forcing a MBR install of 10.7 OSX86. 

Hope you are well.
Stay in touch! 
Brst regards.
-Mike
I'll drop you a line when i start solving meld 1.8 problems again.

target_title: "Copy To Right" feature saved file in /tmp instead of path, with git diffmode, when file does not exist in current commit

note.body: I suppose it is `git difftool` issue but as a workaround you can manually open current working folder in the right pane. Meld GUI allows to do it with Select Folder button in the top of the pane.
